subject: Re: [junit] Re: Categories in JUnit 4.8
msgSnippet: ... In my corrent codebase I could think of something like this: Some of our tests use a class PersistentTestSupport , that helps in setting up tests that use
messageBody:
2009/11/19 Kent Beck <kentb@...>:
> I'm with David on being intrigued by the idea of using arbitrary classes. However, I'm much more interested in experiences than in votes. If someone said, "I went through my code and I could definitely use classes as categories because of X, Y and/or Z," would be compelling to me. Even more compelling is if someone would write the test cases for the new scheme.

In my corrent codebase I could think of something like this:

Some of our tests use a class "PersistentTestSupport", that helps in
setting up tests that use a database.
I could use the same class as a marker for tests that need persistence
and are as such slower.

Greetings,
Malte
